Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Particle Methods for High-Dimensional Integro-Differential Simulation with Application to Aerosol Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research component of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award targets the development of robust and scalable stochastic particle methods for simulating complex, high-dimensional dynamical systems, with a particular research goal of enabling efficient, particle-resolved models of atmospheric aerosols and their climate impact. The research program will involve new mathematical techniques to allow dramatically faster simulations of complex particle systems, as well as making the methods robust and reliable enough to be routinely used by engineers and scientists. Students will be involved in the research at both the graduate and undergraduate levels, and high-school-aged female students will be hosted for a week-long summer camp to explore ideas in dynamics and mechanics. In addition to the diverse student involvement, other deliverables will include new undergraduate educational materials, new mathematical algorithms for dynamical simulation, and open-source code for high-performance particle simulation.

The outcome and benefits of this work will impact both the areas of dynamical systems and the target application of atmospheric aerosol modeling. The improved understanding of aerosol particle processes generated by this research will contribute to a more accurate understanding of climate modeling and to the impact of aerosol particles on human health. In a broader context, this project is a step towards general techniques for computationally analyzing complex dynamical systems in high dimensions, and thus has the potential to contribute to a wide range of current scientific challenges. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit from involvement in the research and through improved classroom instruction, while the high-school-aged female students participating in the summer camp will gain exposure and engagement with engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We developed new algorithms for simulating complex stochastic particle systems, with a focus on atmospheric aerosols and their climate impact. Our algorithms simulate large populations of interacting particles, such as aerosol particles in the air, including interactions between particles and with the surrounding environment. Using our new methods, we demonstrated the ability to directly simulate billions of particles simultaneously, allowing for much more detailed models of atmospheric aerosols than had previously been possible. We released an open source simulation package (PartMC) that incorporates our new algorithms for atmospheric aerosol simulation, making these methods accessible to other researchers. Using this software we collaborated with colleagues in environmental engineering and atmospheric science to validate our methods against laboratory experiments and to use this new software to study many impacts of aerosols on global climate, focusing on cloud-aerosol interactions and aerosol radiative impacts. These studies were able to give the first direct quantification of the errors introduced by simplifications in existing aerosol simulation methods. As part of this project, we created and ran a week-long residential summer camp for high-school girls to introduce them to mechanical engineering. The centerpiece of this camp was a full-week engineering project in which the students worked in small teams to design and build a stereolithographic 3D printer from scratch. This camp has been attended by 24 girls every summer since starting in 2013. Surveys of the students showed that after this experience a large majority of them intended to apply to engineering programs for college.
